faq.question: Are there more hardware controller drivers coming?

answer.p: Yes. Currently, there's one in the queue (1-Wire® based servo controller which is pretty close to my ideal servo controller) and one planned (Pololu 16-servo USB controller).

faq.question: How do you select the hardware controllers to implement the drivers for?

answer.p: First one I bought. The rest were donated. If you want the driver for your controller, consider donating one like others did - by now, the implementation is pretty straightforward, it takes a day or two of straight coding.
Rock solid. It's been used to run inside the DIY Zoning Project code for several years, 24/7/365, non-stop. Never failed.

If you are familiar with the servos, you probably know that they can make a sound that can make you jump, especially caught off guard. The application this project is serving is intended to have the servos operate next to people whose comfort level is paramount, so they must not be scared do death periodically when the servos come to life.
Also, as servos wear down, they sometimes start "growling".
In order to reduce noise related to servo operation, it is possible to shut off the pulse to the servo - it enters the "sleep mode" shortly thereafter. While sleeping, it emits no noise.

As a side effect, this reduces the energy consumption (the sleeping servo goes to a powerdown and consumes about 8mA - thanks again, Chester) and servo wear. Since the servos may be working 24x7, this may be important as well.

faq.question: The Servomaster debug console doesn't fit into my screen!

answer.p: Well, since the advent of 16-servo controllers it doesn't fit into my 1600x1200 screen, either.
This is unfortunate, and there are two things that can possibly be done:

ul.li: Decrease the size of the console elements to make it all smaller. This is quite painful to implement (basically I'll have to change the default font on every single element), and will make the font unreadable, which is unacceptable for me. Don't ask for it, I won't do it.

Make the console frame scrollable. This has already been done, and while it does look ugly, remember that this is just a debug console we're talking about, and I'd hate to put efforts into it if I can do something more useful instead.

answer.p: So, the solution is to just change the frame size - and the contents will become scrollable.

faq.question: Why do I keep getting noClassDefFoundError: javax/comm/UnsupportedCommOperationException?

answer.p: Because you didn't install the JavaCOMM properly. If you keep getting probems even though you've followed the instructions to the letter, try to go with the JRE instead of JDK - copy the comm.jar to ${JRE_HOME}/lib/ext directory.
As a rule of thumb, the newer the version of the JDK/JRE, the less problems you will have.

faq.question: ServoMaster doesn't detect my USB controller, why?

answer.p: This seems to be a peculiarity related to the way javax.usb security is implemented.

Quick fix: chmod -R a+w /proc/bus/usb - this will allow you to test whether the controller is connected. Alternative way is to use usbview utility, it should show the device unconditionally (if it is present, that is).
answer.warning: It is not recommended to run ServoMaster code as root, for security reasons. Nothing in particular, but I'm just paranoid.
answer.p: A more thorough solution involves properly configuring hotplug.
answer.note: Don't forget to check hid if your USB controller is a Phidget.

faq.question: USB permissions are OK, but I still can't see the Phidget!

answer.p: The symptom is usually a complaint about the fact that the USB interface is already claimed.
This is due to the fact that [at least] QuadServo advertises itself as a HID class device, but in fact doesn't properly implement HID specifications (if I remember Chester's explanations right).

Quick fix is: rmmod hid. A more thorough solution would be to add hid to hotplug blacklist, but both of these have an unfortunate side effect of disabling all HID devices. Let's hope that hotplug becomes smart enough to ban individual devices.
answer.note: Module name may be other than hid for some distributions. In particular, for newer Fedora it is phidgetservo.
